reviewText:
Although the PC version of Conflict: Desert Storm is actually quite inferior to the console version, it still stands as the greatest third-person perspective co-operative war-themed videogame to ever exist and I'm going to explain why in extremely thorough detail.

The ability to command a squad actually has significant value in this game. Because the squad consists of merely 2 to 4 unique soldiers, progressing through the game will actually have you grow a heavy attachment toward them (some more than others, due to either preferring a specific weapon set or merely for the personality of the character). For this reason, this game could be considered the original Team Fortress, and the game's sequels further elaborates upon their existing personalities.

As the squad is your most viable resource, you are made to take extra precautions to ensure the safety of every man. This is a very fun task as you are given almost literally complete control over everything your squad does. Don't want Foley to carry his sniper rifle for some reason? Give it to Bradley! Don't even want Foley to participate? Leave him behind! I must admit, the storyline and graphics are sadly not quite up to standard and could use some work, but in the end the gameplay is all that matters, and it more than makes up for the lack of creative in-game dialogue and pleasing textures.

The best thing about this game in my opinion is the freedom you're presented upon entering a mission. I've already explained controlling the squad, but another aspect that many other games don't seem to implement very often is the freedom to be able to tackle the situation anyway you desire. Whether it means trying to find and destroy every enemy vehicle and collect every weapon pickup, or merely sprint through each stage achieving the bare minimum, as long as you achieve the task one way or another it doesn't matter.

This game is great stuff, and I hope to see some of the other games in this franchise in the Steam store sometime, perhaps even with a more stable multiplayer mode or something.

reviewText:
Conflict: Desert Storm is a tactical thirdperson squadbased game centered around a four-man special forces team (British SAS/US Delta Force) during the 1990/1991 invasion of Kuwait. Gameplay mostly consists of completing multiple objectives in a non-linear level, with some missions involving the use of vehicles. Along with a minor empthais on stealth.

Each member of the squad has their own specialization and equipment. Though, the skill system is mostly the soldier's familiarity with their own unique primary weapon, pistol, and a special item (ie: medkit, rocket launcer).


Even though I've enjoyed this game and have done multiple playthroughs, it does have some slight issues, but most of these can be overlooked. For instance, unlike the console versions, the PC version does not have Co-op, but makes up for it with a 8-player deathmatch multiplayer mode.

reviewText:
DO NOT MISS OUT ON THIS EXPERIENCE

Alright, I want to make this quick for you. On the top, I'll do some Pros/Cons, and underneath, I'll write my own thoughts of the game, for any of you who are interested. I will not base this review around nostalgia

PROS:
+Tactical, different gameplay [Switching between all 4 characters at will, inventory/equipment management]

+Incredible fun with friends [EG. Of 2 players, each gets 2 characters, includes item giving, stealing items from corpses if you wish, tactical gameplay is great with friends]

+Character switching [Sick of issuing commands and waiting for â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ AI to do it? You can still do that. Or switch to them, and position them yourself]

+Scavenge items from the warzone including medkits, weapons, ammo, equipment

+Weapon specialists, each character is more efficient with the weapon they were trained to use, and can be trained throughout campaign by continuously using that kind of gun

+Details for realism [If a character dies after going down, they will be replaced in the next mission by a new character, throughout the campaign]

+TANKS ARE â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ING SCARY! But weaker at the back, and can be snuck up on to place C4 or mines against. Several times I have had to kamikaze tanks. Not because I was forced to, just by choice, I guess

CONS:
- Controls can be a BIT dodgy. Not too bad, but I did have to check the keybindings a few times

- Graphics may not be what you can consider to be good. This of course is opinion wise, I appreciate the graphics, but purely just because I played this when I was younger

- Draw distance is a bit... shoddy. Alright, it's very â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥



ALRIGHT, SO, MY OWN OPINION IF YOU GIVE A FLYING â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥

Personally, I love this game. A lot. It's such a tactical-feeling shooter, just feeling the joy of positioning all soldiers, in say, the level where you defend your crashed helicopter from waves of tanks, helis, and ground soldiers. I postioned them all in little cracks in the dry desert terrain, and when I completed doing this, which can be done with precision due to controlling all of them, after I did this, I looked at my line of defence... and I just felt like I had to protect all of these soldiers.

I love how, when all soldiers are down, except for whoever you are that is left, and there's 1 tank, 2 ground soldiers are still standing, and it's up to you to save them. I experienced this, without any medkits, and hardly any ammo on my person. So, I snuck over to our squad leader, Bradley, and took his silenced pistol, then shot the ground soldier as quickly as I could after turning the corner, and the tank did not hear. I then crawled like a lil sneaky worm over to Connors [I was playin as Foley, the sniper] and took his 2 RPGs, and 5 of his medkits, of which he had 6 left. I crouched, and fired both rockets at the tank, the first one hitting the weak side armour, the second hitting the weakest back armour. Tank go boom. I revive all soldiers, and we move on.

FUN â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ING â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ DUDE!!!
